div.p: 1. VI Wednesday.

At eleven O’Clock this morning, I took my granddaughter Mary Louisa, to see the Menagerie of wild beasts which came into the City yesterday, and of which there is the greatest variety that I have ever seen in this Country— There are two elephants, one very large; I think nine feet high; and the other small, not more than five. A Rhinoceros, the most perfect one I ever saw— A large lion— A Royal Bengal Tyger remarkably fine— Two spotted Hyenas, with fiend like looks— A Zebra, a Tapir, a Gnu, a Jackall— A Camel, a White Bear, a wilderness of Monkies and Parrots, an Eagle, a wolf, wild cats, small spotted Leopards, an Ounce, and sundry smaller animals, with which I was not acquainted. One of the keepers went into almost all the dens, and held the beasts in perfect submission to him— He kept the Lion, as crouching; and obedient as a Lap dog— But he did
not think fit to associate with the white Bear, the Tyger, or the Hyenas— There was a Captain Jack, scarlet uniformed monkey, who rode round some time, on a small poney, and a round dickey, was placed in Saddle form on the back of the large Elephant, and two sets of little girls from eight to twelve years old, seated therein rode two or three times round— The tent was well filled with Spectators and I met there several of my acquaintance— Among them Walter Hellen, whom I invited to go home and dine with us; but who declined, being obliged to return to Alexandria— I went next to the City Hall, but the Mayor and Register Hewitt were again both absent— I left my deeds from B. O. Tyler and promised to call again— Then I went to the National Intelligencer, and got engaged again in a two hours conversation with Seaton— Came home and found a half-witted man, subject to nervous contortions, who had invited himself to dine with us which he did— Mrs Frye was also here— As I was walking home, I found in the Pennsylvania Avenue a silver tea spoon marked with a C.— I thought it perhaps a poisson d’Avril, but picked it up and brought it home.
2. V.45. Thursday

I called at the Secretary of State’s Office, and asked Mr Forsyth to permit me to send to the Department a small box containing fifty copies of my Oration upon the Life and Character of La Fayette to be forwarded to his Son; which he said he would do— The Committee of Arrangements requested me to take charge of them— Mr Forsyth spoke to me of the boundary controversy between Ohio and Michigan, and of the question of our Northeastern boundary with Great-Britain— He said there was a recent Resolution of the Legislature of the State of Maine, approving of the rejection of the award made by the King of the Netherlands— He seemed to lean to the Ohio side on the question of boundary with Michigan; and weary of the North eastern boundary question— At the Capitol, in the Library I found Mr Joseph Russell— I called for Ward’s History of the Law of Nations, before Grotius, and for Bodin, de la Republique— I spent two hours in turning over the leaves of these two Works— Ward’s book I have always thought a very valuable one, not only as a historical monument, but as tracing the principles of international intercourse to their foundations, and as rendering justice to the high and extraordinary character of Grotius, the founder of the modern Science of the Law of Nations— I looked over the Chapter titles of Bodin’s Republic to see if any thing could be found of the division of powers into Legislative Executive and Judicial but met with nothing to the purpose— Bodin, like Hobbes and Filmer, considers Sovereign Power, as indivisible and illimitable; though he marks the difference between those who make the Laws, and the magistracy who execute them— I sought in Chalmers’s Biographical Dictionary for the Articles Hobbes and Filmer, which I found— The latter very short— Returning home I stop’d at the National Intelligencer Office, and spoke to Deeble the Bookbinder about the transmission of the fine Copies of my Oration to the members of Congress. He came to my house and took fifty Copies which I had addressed. Mrs Klapp came to spend a few days with Mary.
3. VI. Friday.

The child Fanny, is recovering from her severe intermittent fever, but her mother and grandmother are much indisposed with heavy colds— I called at Mrs Wolfendens for a settlement of her rent and she gave me a bill of half her quarters rent for putting up a coal grate— Walking round the Capitol, Franklin E. Plummer, a member of the late House of Representatives from Mississippi was starting from Mrs Dunn’s in a Carryall, and asked me to take a seat with him which I did; he was driving to the War Department, where I left him— He said he thought Poindexter had been imprudent, in his great dinner Speech at Philadelphia.— The whigs of Philadelphia have made a magnificent Banquet at the Arch-Street Theatre; in honour of Mr Poindexter; against whom, the basest conspiracy ever witnessed in this Country has been defeated and exposed—growing out of the attempt of Richard Lawrence to assassinate the President, at the Capitol, on the 29th. of January, the day of Warren R Davis’s funeral. Immediately after Lawrence’s two pistols missed fire the President said it was a Poindexter affair— Soon after a man named Coltman a member of the Common Council, suborned two men named Foy and Stewart to make affidavit’s that they had seen Lawrence go to Poindexter’s house, and talking with him, a day or two before the attempted Assassination— The President was treasuring up these Affidavits, when they were communicated to D. J. Pearce, when visiting at the House, and by him to Southworth, a newspaper correspondent and Reporter— The facts got thus into the newspapers— Poindexter, wrote to the President demanding an explanation but received no answer— Poindexter demanded an investigating Committee of the Senate; and there was one appointed who detected and exposed the conspiracy, so far at least as to fasten the Subornation by Coltman; and the falsehood of the two affidavits— They reported a triumphant vindication of Poindexter’s innocence, and the report was unanimously accepted by the Senate— The public indignation is thus transformed, from the Assassin of the person to the Assassin of character, and Jackson himself bears no small portion of the public odium. The Philadelphia whigs turn it to political account; and give a great festival to Poindexter, to celebrate his escape from the conspiracy— Poindexter avails himself of the occasion to make a flaming opposition Speech, which may be excusable in him but which seems to me not well judged— The whole affair is sickening to me, and looks too much as if we were running into the manners of the Italian Republics.
4. V:30. Saturday

I make for myself occupations which absorb all my time, leaving none for others which ought not to be neglected— I forgot to call again this morning at Mrs Wolfendens as I had promised but did call at the Intelligencer Office, with fifty written directions to members of the
late House of Representatives, to be pasted in before the title page of the Copies of the La Fayette Oration, to be sent to them in my name. At the Congress Library I met Mr William Pitt Adams of the British Legation— I took out The History of the Revolution of 1688 by Sir James Mackintosh, and Hallam’s Constitutional History of England. my object was to ascertain if I could find in them any discussion upon the division of powers in Government—but I had not time for sufficient consultation I looked into Cooper’s Translation of Justinian’s Institutes for definitions— But under the denomination of Law, he includes the Plebiscitum, the Senatus Consultum, the Principis Mandatum, and even the Responsa Prundentium— After returning home I looked into Horace, for the division of Powers and found, in the Epistle to Augustus

lg.l: Cum tot sustineas, et tanta negotia, solus,
Res Italas armis tuteris, moribus ornes,

div.p: here is Legislative—Executive—and Moral authority, all exercised by one man, but with the distinction between them explicitly drawn— I was anxious to see how Pope had applied these Lines to George the second.

lg.l: While you, great Patron of Mankind! sustain
The balanc’d world, and open all the main;
Your country, chief in arms abroad defend
At home, with morals, arts and Laws amend;—

div.p: fulsome enough in all conscience—what he means by opening all the main I cannot exactly tell— Chief in Arms is Montesquieu’s executive for the Laws of Nations— But Horace does not confine the defence of arms to agency abroad; nor does he say any thing of Amendment in Arts— There was a heavy thunderstorm this Evening; followed by a Northeast gale—in the midst of which I had a visit from General Scott. He thinks that if Edward Livingston’s Letters communicated to Congress on the 6th. of February in answer to my call, should reach France before the Appropriation for indemnity is made, or if the Peel and Wellington Ministry should be dismissed the French chamber of deputies will not make the appropriation at-all. The General was quite studiously civil—
5. VI. Sunday

My wife and Mary are both afflicted with distressing and obstinate coughs, and Fanny was again so unwell that Dr Huntt was sent for, and came— I attended morning and afternoon at the Presbyterian Church, the weather being stormy, and no evening Service at St. John’s. Mr Smith’s morning Sermon was from Matthew 12.49. “And he stretched forth his hand toward his disciples, and said, Behold my mother, and my brethren!” It was the most liberal discourse that I ever heard from a Presbyterian Clergyman— He assumed that Jesus throughout his life shewed a constant regard for all the relations of consanguinity, and that in saying that his disciples were his disciples were his mother and his brethren, he plainly meant to indicate that his affection for his disciples was equally strong and
tender, with that of the most powerful ties of nature in domestic life—and the doctrine that he deduced from this was, that the same tenderness of affection ought to subsist between the disciples themselves— That to whatever denomination of Christians they belong, they are bound to consider all other Christians as children and brethren of one and the same family— This is true Christianity— The afternoon Sermon was from Luke 7–8. “For I also am a man set under authority having under me, Soldiers, and I say unto one, Go, and he goeth; and to another, Come, and he cometh; and to my servant, Do this, and he doeth it.” He noticed a difference in the relation of this event by Matthew, from the narrative in Luke. I met on the Square a stranger, who was going to St. John’s Church, and enquired of me, if there was to be no meeting there. I said no, and he then asked if I could shew him to any place of worship, where there would be preaching— I took him with me, and gave him a seat in my pew— He talked so constantly and so oddly on the way, that I thought him hardly of sane mind. He appeared to sleep nearly the whole Sermon time; and remained in the Church after it was over, I suppose to talk with Mr Smith— I read the 19th. of Dr Bancroft’s Sermons—Evangelical Obedience, necessary to Salvation—and the 20th On conversion— I made also a paraphrase of the 7th. Ode of the 4th. Book of Horace, to Torquatus—
6. VI: Monday.

My occupations, absorb my time, and perplex my mind, beyond any thing that ever happened to me before— My wife and Mary, continue both with violent coughs, and my correspondence continually runs in arrear. My paraphrase of the Ode of Horace to Torquatus, led me to an enquiry into the character as exemplified in Horace’s Odes of lyric poetry; and thence to the same species of composition as exemplified by Pindar, and Anacreon, Boileau, Baptiste Rousseau, Voltaire, Cowley, Dryden, Pope, Collins, Gray, Byron, Burns, Dibdin, all the English Songsters, the French Chansonniers, and above all, the Psalms. There is one character infinitely diversified in them all—but what are the essential characters of Horace’s Ode’s— 1. Unity—a seminal idea, pervading the whole Ode. 2 Rich imagery. 3 picturesque descriptions of nature 4. Sublime and lofty Sentiment. 5. Maxims of wisdom sententiously expressed— 6. harmonious versification; a beauty of which we can have but a very faint idea, from ignorance of the pronunciation of the language, and of the various measures of his verse— Many of his amatory odes however are grossly indelicate— The subjects of others are uninteresting, or unintelligible— Many of them refer to manners, no longer existing—the allusions to the mythology, and to the astrology of the time are frequent; and not always clear— Those to the roman history, and to individuals cotemporaries of the Poet, are common— There are Bacchanalian and Love Songs, and some religious hymns, of which the carmen Saeculare is the chief— A remarkable difference between his Odes to the Gods and the Psalms of David is that his devotion never dwells upon any moral attribute in his deities— Another remarkable thing in Horace is, that although a professed Epicurean, his most admirable Sentiments are from the Stoic School— I walked to the Capitol, and at the Office of the Clerk of the House made enquiries respecting sundry Bills and reports relating to the Ohio and Michigan boundary question— I found
several bills, and the report of the Committee of the Territories of the House, made on the 11th of March 1834— I still want much information upon the boundary question, to be prepared to act upon it, at the next Session of Congress— The man whom I took with me yesterday afternoon to Church, came this day to see me— His name is Stephen Bruce he is from Billerica in Massachusetts where he says he has a Sister named Mrs Upton. He appears to be underwitted or insane

div.p: 7. VI. Tuesday.

I am still much distracted with diversity of employment, and a craving of further information upon various subjects— I walked to the Capitol, and obtained at the Clerk’s Office, a copy of the Bill reported 26. February 1833. by the Committee of the Territories to authorise the People of the Eastern division of the Territory of Michigan, to form a Constitution of State Government, and to be admitted into the Union, on the footing of the original States—also the memorial from the Legislative Council of Michigan presented the 29th. of December last, with the returns of the Census of the Territory, and the large lithographed map shewing the location of the disputed lands—of which Burch gave me three copies— I went into the Library, and read nearly two hours in Hallam’s Constitutional History of England— I took the period of the Revolution of 1688 and found an account of the Petition of right and the Bill of rights— He has a very high opinion of William the third, and a very bad one of Queen Anne— I looked into the Biographical dictionary for the Article of Sir Robert Filmer, and found that he died in 1647. of course before the Execution of Charles the first— His books must therefore have been written in the heat of the civil war— They must have been many years before Sidney undertook to refute them, and yet longer before they were demolished by Locke— I see nothing obnoxious in them, but what is equally so in Hobbes— There is something very plausible in the idea that parental authority is the foundation of civil Government. Hobbes and Filmer, both argue much from the Scriptures of the old Testament but there is in truth nothing there to sustain the pretension that Government was derived from parental authority— From the time of the flood there is always a compact or Covenant, of God with Abraham; with Isaac, with Jacob— Then Joseph becomes prime Minister to the king of Egypt, and he and all the children of Israel, are subjects of the Egyptian monarchy till delivered by Moses and Aaron— They had a special commission from Heaven, and the Law from Sinai was received as a covenant— I continued writing this Evening to my Son.
8. VI. Wednesday.

My wife is much indisposed, with the complicated disease with which she suffers every Spring and fall— She was bled this morning by Dr. Huntt and was confined to her bed almost all the remainder of the day— I walked to the National Intelligencer Office, and left there 50 papers to be pasted into the copies of my La Fayette Oration, and sent to members of the House of Representatives. I had some Conversation with Mr Seaton, and brought home newspapers containing a months European news from 11. Feby to 12 March— The sudden death of the Emperor of Austria on the 3d. the Meeting of the newly chosen British Parliament—the choice of the opposition candidate Abercrombie, as Speaker of the House of Commons.
No very encouraging news from France.— On coming home I found Mrs Frye, at the house, and she dined with us. Bernard Gilpin the Quaker, who married a Sister of the late Roger Johnson’s wife, and who lives about twenty miles on the road to Frederick made his promised visit— He had dined, but had his horse put up and stayed while we dined he kept me nearly three hours, talking all the time, and the monotous uninteresting tone which operates upon me as an irresistible narcotic— In the midst of his discourse, Stephen Bruce the half-idiot came in and commenced his discourse, which I however immediately stop’d and he went away— Mr Gilpin remarked his insanity— I walked down to Mr Frye’s, and sat with him until Mrs Frye came home with Mrs Klapp and Mary. I returned with them— So large a portion of the day was wasted that much of my writing was abridged.
9. VI. Thursday

My wife is yet severely suffering and kept her bed great part of the day. Walk to the Capitol and round the square— In the Library of the House of Representatives, I looked for the debates in the Senate on four Resolutions offered by H Clay on the 7th. of March 1834 for the abridgement of Executive Patronage— I could not find them, but was rather more successful in the Library— There I found references there to former debates in the same body 12. Jany 1830. a notice by Mr Barton, that at the next Executive Session of the Senate he should move to transfer to the Legislative Journal the discussion, upon the Constitutional powers of the President and Senate, relating to appointments and removals— This was pronounced out of Order— (Register of Debates, Vol. 6 p. 11.)— Then on the 21st. of April p 367 Barton p. 385–396. Holmes— These refer back to T. H. Benton’s report on Executive Patronage, made 4 May1826.— Register of Debates Vol. 2. p. 672. and Appendix p. 133 to 138: the Report and the six Bills— Mr Calhoun’s Bill is a mutilated copy of one of those Bills— These debates, gave me some further insight into Calhoun’s motives, as well as to the slovenly manner in which he has done his business— They engaged me till past three at the Library, and the whole evening at home— I could not quite finish my Letter to my Son Charles— Giusta was here for the receipt to Montandon which I gave him—
10. VI. Friday.

My wife and Mary are better, though still seriously unwell— My own time is swallowed up, in seeking information upon subjects which there is reason to apprehend will come up for consideration at the next Session of Congress— The further I press my enquiries into the Patronage Bill, the more occasion I find to reflect; to pause and to prepare— The reasoning of Mr Clay, of Mr Calhoun and of Mr Webster on this subject, appears to me, all shallow and sophistical—but they speak to popular prejudices and it is true of great masses of men as it is of individuals— He who is convinced against his will, Is of the same opinion still— The task of eradicating prejudices seems to be desperate— I have read the opinion of the Attorney General of the United States on the boundary question between Michigan and Ohio— The Secretary of War told me that this opinion was against the claim of right on the part
of the State of Ohio, and that it did not touch upon the right of Congress finally to settle the question— As I understand the opinion, it does deny the present right of the State of Ohio to resort to force to seize upon the Jurisdiction of the land, as it has done, but his argument advises the President to interdict resistance by the Territorial Government of Michigan to the usurpation of Jurisdiction by Ohio; and it concedes that Congress by accepting the Constitution of the State of Ohio, did reserve to itself the right of assenting thereafter to the proposed boundary— The opinion therefore, as I understand it surrenders both the jurisdiction and the possession to Ohio— Mr Benjamin F. Butler the present Attorney General, is the pupil, protegé and law partner of Martin van Buren, Vice-President, and candidate for the succession to the Presidency. Mr Butler’s opinion upon the boundary question is perfumed with the thirty-five electoral votes of Ohio, Indiana, and Illinois— I called at the Intelligencer Office, and left with Mr Seaton, the remainder of the names of the Members of the House of Representatives to whom copies of my La Fayette Oration are to be sent.— I asked Seaton if they intended to discontinue the publication of the Congressional Register of Debates— He did not know— I rode round the Capitol this afternoon, with Mrs Klapp, Mary and her two children— And in the Evening began an 8th. Letter to Charles.
11. VI. Saturday.

I finished my 8th. Letter to my Son, upon the transactions of the last Session of Congress, and the anticipations of the next Session— I have written them for a memorial to be preserved by him for his children of incidents memorable in the declining days of my political life— They present a painful and anxious anticipation for the remnant of my time; but in the resolution to fulfil my duties the remnant of my days must abide the results that await them. I wrote also to George W. La Fayette, a reply to his Letter of 21. October, and to accompany the 50 copies of the Oration, on the life and character of his father which I was requested by Mr Hubbard of the Committee of Arrangements to transmit to him— Edward Wyer was here, and had a long conversation with me, upon his own concerns and on many other subjects— He is for Hugh Lawson White, as the successor to the Presidency— The Elections to Congress now in progress in Virginia, indicate increasing opposition to the Administration while it has been victorious in Connecticut— The whole delegation from that State is changed. It is another downfall of federalism under the name of whigs— The geographical interests and impulses are coming in to weigh down the Scales of the Election— The nomination of Daniel Webster, as a Candidate for the Presidency by the Whigs of the Massachusetts Legislature has settled the State of Connecticut for Van Buren, and Massachusetts will stand alone in her glory— I had only time this day to walk round the Capitol before dinner.
12. VI:15. Sunday.

Attended this morning at the Presbyterian Church, and heard Mr Smith from 1. Thessalonians 5.21. “Prove all things; hold fast that which is good.” He said that the words of his text, had no special and immediate reference to the subject of his discourse, which was the form of Government of the Presbyterian Church— That the original form of Christian Church Government, naturally arose from the Synagogues of the Jews— That the
the great majority of the first Christians were Jews, though from the first there were among them many Gentiles or heathens— That the Christian Churches were formed on the model not of the Heathen or of the Jewish Temples but of the Jewish Synagogues— The Temples both Jewish and Heathen, being devoted to the worship of Sacrifices and served by Priests—while in the Synagogues there was neither Priest nor Sacrifices; but the Service was performed by Teachers and Elders, and resembled the Services now performed in most of the Christian Churches of almost all denominations— He then gave some account of the origin, character and authority of the teachers and ruling elders of the presbyterian Church; but wished his hearers to understand that the form of Church Government was altogether subordinate and secondary to the essentials of Religion, which were the same in all Christian Churches— He finally said that he should perhaps pursue this subject in his next Sunday morning’s discourse, but it was not certain— Mr Smith’s mind seems to be labouring with some difficulty, relating the discipline or doctrines of his Church— Mr and Mrs Frye and Thomas dined with us; and Mr W. S. Smith was here towards evening— I attended after dinner at St John’s Church— Mr Hawley read the Evening Service for the Sunday before Easter; and preached from Psalm 25.8. [“]Good and upright is the Lord: therefore will he teach Sinners in the way” and the three following verses. I finished my Series of Letters to my Son.
13. VI. Monday.

I intended after finishing the Series of Letters to Charles, to devote myself, until I can return to Quincy to my private concerns and duties here; but this morning I got engaged again with J. C. Calhoun’s patronage Bill, which passed the Senate at their last Session. I had remarked the excessive ill-composition of the Bill, without knowing the cause of it, but on comparing it with Benton’s Bill of May 1826. I found the cause; and it gave me new matter for reflection— It made me dissatisfied with the draft of a Speech which I had written, and which now appears to me week and inefficient for want of method and arrangement— Extemporaneous debate cannot be methodical; but where there is so much matter, as I have on this Bill it cannot be introduced and disposed of but by a formal written discourse— I began therefore a second draft of a Speech; and was engaged with it the whole day, except when drawn off for other indispensable business— John Kennedy was here and took up his note to my Son of 3. July last, and settled for his rent to the close of the year— I went to the National Intelligencer Office, and saw Mr Seaton— He shewed me a Letter from Daniel Brent, of 14. March who thinks the indemnity Appropriation will be made, unless there should be a reaction— Seaton lent me a file of Galignani’s Messenger from 5 to 14 March— After dinner I walked to Mr Frye’s to make some enquiries of him— One was whether such offices now existed as the Apothecary General and Assistant Apothecaries General— I enquired also something about the final settlement of the Estate of the late Walter Hellen—whose youngest Son, Walter has just come of age—and concerning the importation of a Quarter Cask of Madeira wine— He will make enquiries— I found after returning home that
the Offices of Apothecary General, and his Assistants were tacitly abolished by the Act reducing the Military Establishment of 2. March 1821—and yet they were both included in Benton’s Patronage Bill of 4. May 1826— Dr Huntt was here, and told me that W. S. Archer had withdrawn from the contest of his election; seeing that he would certainly be defeated— Two of his Counties out of five had voted— I answered a Letter from George W. La Fayette, acknowledging the receipt of my Oration.
14. VI Tuesday.

Mr Frye sent me this morning his Son Thomas with a note, mentioning that the Offices of Apothecary General, and Assistants were abolished by the Act of 2. March 1821. and he sent me the Army Registers of March and May 1821. in the first of which those Offices are included, and they are omitted in the second— I returned to Mr Seaton his file of Galignani’s Messengers, in which I find an account of my Speech in the House of Representatives on the 7th. of February, and my explanation of the 14th. both retranslations into English from French Translations. I had taken yesterday to the Intelligencer Office the Directions to the Members of the Senate for the copies of my Oration to be sent to them— Mary and Mrs Klapp dined and spent the day at Mr Frye’s— I was still so irresistibly drawn to the Patronage-bill, that I found no time for attention to any thing else, and my private affairs and correspondence are neglected—one idea, penetrates, fills, and absorbs my mind— It leads to Distraction apropos of which, Richard Lawrence, the man who snap’d two pistols at the President on the 29th. of January in the Capitol at Warren R. Davis’s funeral was tried last Saturday at the Circuit Court, and found by the Jury, not guilty, by reason of insanity.
15. VI. Wednesday.

I was brought to a point at last in remodelling my projected Speech upon the Patronage-Bill— Almost all that I had written before, now seems to me stale flat, and unprofitable, and yet I must work it almost all up into the new frame. I am yet much at a loss how to methodize for effect— I am sure I have the argument unanswerable— But how often have I had it, never answered and never successful— Mrs Frye was here this morning, and went to St. John’s Church where the service for Wednesday in Passion week was performed— Mrs Klapp left us this afternoon, and returned to her Sisters—Mrs Twiggs at the Navy-Yard. I had barely time to walk round the Capitol Hill, and to call at the Post-Office to enquire for my Letter to George W. La Fayette which was taken there yesterday by mistake— They said it was gone to New-York, and would there be put into the packet bag for Havre— I made out a duplicate. Thomas B. Johnson was here this morning, and I had a long conversation with him upon good and evil.— He thinks the latter predominates in this world; and that there is no retributive Justice— By an industrious Evening I retrieved the immediate arrears of my Diary, but left my Correspondence lagging.
16. V:30 Thursday

The morning was absorbed in writing a Letter to my Son— I then called at the Office of the Secretary of State, and left with Mr Forsyth the duplicate of my Letter to George W. La Fayette, of which the original has gone by the mail. He told me that he has received the box containing the fifty copies of the oration on the Life and Character of La Fayette, for George W. La Fayette, which would be taken by a Messenger whom he should send to New-York and who was to go to-morrow— Mr Forsyth said he had Letters from Mr Livingston since the appointed of the French Ministry with the Duke de Broglie at its head. He had also Letters from Mr Rush who had seen the Governor of the State of Ohio, without having much influence over his warlike determination.— He was then going to see the Governor of Michigan at Detroit— I walked round the Capitol Hill, and called at the Office of the Secretary of the Senate, to enquire for Documents of the years 1813 and 1814. I found them in the Legislative and Executive Journals of the Senate— In the Evening at home I resumed the Search— It was a motion first made by Christopher Gore, on the 29th. of July 1813. to declare the appointment during the recess of the Senate of Ministers to negotiate Peace with Great Britain, unconstitutional, and to protest against it— On the first of August it was postponed to the first Monday in December— At the next Session Mr Gore renewed his motion on the 28th. of February 1814— It was then ordered that the debate should be held with open doors, and made the order of the day for the 7th. of March and from that day it was repeatedly debated till the 12th. of April, when it was again postponed to the first Monday in December— The yeas and nays were not taken.
17. VI. Friday.— Good Friday.

There was Church service this morning at St. John’s Church; but Mrs Frye declined staying to dine with us— I called at the National Intelligencer Office, and enquired for the remaining copies of my La Fayette Oration, of which Mr Deeble the binder afterwards brought me 102. This completes the number furnished me by the Committee— Mr Mercer came into the Office while I was there— I congratulated him upon his re-election to Congress— Not more than a fortnight since, he had a prospect of two opponents—one Jackson man, and one whig: they have now both withdrawn, and he has no opposition— He says his two opponents were brought out by the same person— He appears to be much exasperated against President Jackson, and very bitter against Van Buren. He says that he dislikes very much Mr White, but will vote for him in preference to Van Buren. I told him I thought the electioneering contest would take a geographical turn; and would go altogether North and South— This is very apparent, but what will be its effect upon the movements at the next Session of Congress.— This afternoon I walked to Mr. T. B. Johnsons but he was not at home— Much of the day was absorbed in examining the contest between the President and Senate upon the nomination and renomination of the Government Directors of the Bank of the United States, and the contrast between the Senatorial arguments in that case, and on Mr Calhoun’s Patronage Bill.
18. VI. Saturday.

The two children Mary Louisa and Georgiana Frances, went this morning to Captain Twiggs’s at the Navy-Yard, and spent the day there— Their mother and grandmother went for them towards Evening, and brought them home— Mr Herring of New-York was here— He is engaged upon a work called the National Gallery of Portraits, for which he wants that of my father, with a biographical narrative— He has written to me two or three times upon this subject, Letters, which from the multiplicity of business and of cares with which I am over-laboured, I have neglected to answer— He has sent me messages by Edward Everett and one or two other persons through whom I have apologized from my failure, and I repeated the apology now, with which he professed to be satisfied— He wished to have engraved for his book, the full length portrait of my father, painted by Copley, in 1783 now at Harvard University, Cambridge, and the Kit-cat, painted by Stewart when my father was President of the United States— He also desired to have the Portrait of my mother; painted at the same time— I told him they might be used for the purpose of engraving, and he said he expected to be in Boston, in the course of the Summer, and would come to see me at Quincy— He spoke also with great approbation of the Portrait of me lately painted by Durand, and thought it the strongest likeness of me that he had ever seen. He said he had advised Mr Durand to commence the engraving of it immediately— I promised to call on Mr Herring upon my homeward way, if I should stay long enough in New-York— Mr Clements was here to hire one of my small houses, but we could not agree upon the terms. My excursion for the day was only a walk round the Capitol Hill; and on my return I met Edward Wyer who walked with me to my door— He told me of a beggarly famished man, who got into the President’s House last night; and at two O’Clock this morning, roused him twice in bed, by attempting to get into his chamber, which was locked— He roused the men in the house; who took him; and he had nothing to say but that he was hungry. They shut him up in the Stable, from which he escaped this morning before daylight— I wasted a large portion of this day, in searching, for a foolish saying of Falstaff in Shakespear, which after all I did not find.
19. VI. Sunday— Easter-day.

Rain all the morning. I attended at the Presbyterian Church, where Mr Smith preached from John 12:43. [“]For they loved the praise of men, more than the praise of God.” he did not continue the subject of his last Sunday morning’s discourse— He gave notice that on account of the inclemency of the weather, there would be no afternoon service. There was immediately after the Sermon, an Easter Anthem sung, by the singers in the front gallery— There was no Evening service at St. John’s Church, and I had no opportunity to attend any where after dinner— I read Bancroft’s Sermon 23
on the doctrine of immortality preached on Christmas day—and the 24th. on the duties enjoined by the fourth commandment—to keep the Sabbath day holy— The second of these discourses, is more satisfactory to me than the first— I walked out towards evening, and called on Mr T. B. Johnson, with whom I sat in conversation about an hours— In the pursuit of my enquiries concerning this Patronage Bill, I got engaged with Gales and Seaton’s Register of debates Vol. 6. part 1. upon the debates in the Senate of the Winter of 1829–30. the first Session of the 21st. Congress; and of Jackson’s Administration— It absorbed my attention so intensely that the day was gone, and I had done nothing— It seemed a trial of strength between the makers of long Speeches, who could hold out longest, and wander widest from the proper subject of discussion— A very large portion of the debate upon Executive patronage was wasted upon Foot’s Resolution respecting the Public Lands— That debate was one of the earliest results of that coalition between the South and the West, to sacrifice the manufacturing and free labour interest of the North and East to the Slave-holding interest of the South, by the plunder of the public Lands surrendered by the South to the new Western States— This was the secret of that combined, and simultaneous attack of Hayne and Benton upon the Eastern Section of the Union, so manfully and ably met and repelled by Webster and Sprague— The Jackson Administration had been formed upon this combination and had drawn New-York and Pennsylvania into its vortex— It is rather surprising that the sacrifice of the public Lands was not then entirely consummated— Benton was the founder of this project— Clay had built his reputation as a Statesman and raised his ladder to the Presidency upon internal improvement, of the Western Country— He had connected himself with the free labour interest of the North in this pursuit; Benton who had been one of his partizans till then saw he could supplant him, by purchasing of the South the plunder of the public Lands, and selling to them the Western interest of internal improvement— This was the governing impulse of the joint movement of Hayne and Benton, against the East and North in that debate. Why can I pursue this subject no further?— Mary was seized violently this morning with a return of chills and fever, and was confined the whole day to her bed.
20. VI. Monday.

Mary was still confined all day to her bed— Her brother Johnson was here this afternoon, but did not come in to visit me— Dr Huntt was here. This occurrence, has disconcerted all my arrangements for returning to Quincy, as I cannot go and leave her ill here, and as these returns of chills and fevers are apt to be exceedingly obstinate— I received a Letter from the Revd Dr Sprague of Albany, which I answered— Walked round the Capitol Hill before dinner, and to alleviate my anxiety and distress, gave up as much as possible my mind to my researches upon Executive Patronage— I read over most of the debates in the Senate, through the memorable Session of 1829–30. and made out a list of all the Speakers on the numerous questions involving this Constitutional principle— I perused also the Executive Journal of that Session, published as an Appendix to the Legislative Journal of the same Session— It was Webster’s Speeches and replies to Hayne in that Session, in the debates on Foot’s Resolution, which raised his reputation to the highest pitch, and not without reason— They are monuments of eloquence, and debateable power— Neither he nor Hayne in their Speeches on that Resolution introduced the Patronage question
but Foot himself and others did—particularly Clayton, Johnston, Grundy, Livingston and Bibb— The great effort of every member was to shew that he could make a tiresome long Speech— Webster however, putting his whole stake upon the answer to Hayne, rather affectedly avoided noticing Benton, who was the great and real assailant— The Policy of this is extremely doubtful— It seems to me upon a review of the whole debate that Webster should have answered Benton as well as Hayne—that he should have assumed the offensive against both, and exposed the profligate combination between Nullification and the Robbery of the Public Lands which urged the joint attack on Benton and Hayne upon the East— This he did not do— He kept wholly on the defensive as to the East; and suffered Hayne to sacrifice, all the rights of the old States to their portion of the public Lands, with impunity— This was the deadly poison of that league which brought in the Jackson Administration, and it has never yet been exposed— The failure of its consummation hitherto has been owing to the breach between Jackson and Calhoun, brought about by Van-Buren—to the consequent precipitation of the nullification rebellion of South-Carolina—to the compromise between Clay and Calhoun, and to Clay’s Land-Bills, which though defeated by Jackson’s veto have yet defeated or rather delayed the total sacrifice of the public Lands, which yet Jackson openly recommended in his message of December 1832— My wife and two Grand-children, narrowly escaped severe injury if not worse, by the slamming to of a window blind, which smashed four squares of large window-glass in the dining room, where they were standing— Fanny escaped with a slight scratch on the head—the others were unhurt—blessed be God.—
21. VI. Tuesday.

Mr Johnson and Mrs Frye were here this morning— I walked to the Capitol, and visited the Congress Library— Examined in the first Volume of Cranch’s Reports the opinion of the Supreme Court of the United States in the case of Marbury and Madison, in two or more passages of which the Court expressly say that by the Constitution of the United States the power of appointing as well as of nominating to Office is vested in the President— In the late debates of the Senate upon the Patronage Bill, it was maintained by several of the Senators, and especially by Webster that the appointing power is vested in the President and Senate, and it is upon this false statement that nearly the whole of their arguments to the support of the Bill are directed— I found also in the Library a Volume of Reports to the English House of Commons, in which were two voluminous Reports of J. Bowring upon the Public Accounts Revenues and expenditures of France. They are full of exceedingly useful information— I find by it that the annual revenue and expenditure of France, exceeds one thousand millions of Franks; or about two hundred Millions of dollars— The population of France is about double that of the United States— Its expences are ten times more than ours—Army, Navy,
and civil list are about ten fold greater than ours— After dinner I walked to Mr Frye’s, and had conversation with him concerning the final settlement of the Estate of the former Mr Walter Hellen, and the distribution of his property between his surviving children— It has been postponed until the youngest child, Walter should come of age which was about one month since— There are however now other delays interposed, and Johnson Hellen says he cannot attend to it, until the Session of the circuit Court for the District shall be over; which will not be in less than five or six weeks— Evening at home, much engaged and deeply anxious— Mary, still confined to her bed.
22. VI. Wednesday—

Morning swallowed up, in a fruitless search for Alfred Thomas, the black boy’s indenture for the purpose of making it over— The boy was bound to my Son for seven years, of which four or five are yet unexpired; but he is unmanageable, and to be transferred to a superior who will deal with him more energetically— I could not find the indenture, but in looking over the papers, brought multitudes of remembrances to the mind which overwhelmed me with anguish— Oh! the bitterness of joys forever gone, and remembered in the sharp pangs of present affliction— I tore myself at last away from farther search and took my daily walk round the Capitol Hill— After dinner I answered a Letter from Elias Phinney, of Lexington, Massachusetts, inviting me in the name of the Inhabitants of that town, to attend the celebration of the Anniversary of the 19th. of April 1775, which they fixed for Monday the 20th. the 19th. being this year on Sunday— They are erecting a monument in honour of the martyrs of that day— And their remains were to be disinterred, and reburied together under this monument— And Edward Everett delivered an Oration upon the occasion— The invitation to me to attend was sent to Quincy, and thence came here, so late that my answer could not have reached Mr Phinney before the day.— My distracting cares, and very troublesome private concerns destroy the regularity both of my Correspondence and of my Diary— They break in also upon my enquiries and observations upon the Senatorial Patronage Bill of the last Session. The Connecticut and New-York City Elections have gone entirely for the Van-Buren succession to Jackson— The Webster whigs boast of a victory in Rhode-Island; at least so far as to ensure an election of a whig to the Senate of the United States. I wrote this Evening till overcome by weariness. Mary still keeps her bed— Mrs Frances Ramsay, daughter of Thomas Munroe, and wife of George Ramsay died this day of a puerperal fever—
23. VI. Thursday

I received Letters from James S. M’Cauley, Secretary to the Eucleian Society, attached to the University of the City of New-York, inviting me to deliver an Oration at their next Commencement some time in July; and a Letter from the Revd. Dr. Matthews Chancellor of the University urging me to comply with the invitation in behalf of two literary Societies. I answered immediately both the Letters, declining. Mr Hawley came and introduced a Clergyman as the Head of the College at Annapolis, Dr Humphries— Mrs Frye dined with us at 3. O’Clock. At 4. I attended at Mr Thomas Munroe’s the funeral of his daughter Mrs Frances Ramsay, who died yesterday of a child-bed fever, leaving an infant about a fortnight old— She was a familiar friend
of Mary’s, and she has been much affected by her illness and decease— The funeral was numerously attended—particularly by Ladies— There was no service at the House, but Mr Hawley officiated at the grave— She was buried at the cemetery of St. John’s Church; at the right hand of the road to Meridian Hill— I met Mr Frye at the House and he rode with me—returned after the funeral to my house, where he found his wife— Mr Forsyth, the Secretary of State’s Carriage returning from the funeral broke down in front of my house— Mrs Forsyth’s mother, Mrs Meigs, and General and Mrs Macomb were in the Carriage, but no one was hurt— Mr S. B. Barrell was here this Evening—about ten days from Boston; where he says it is yet winter. Mary was this day better.
24. VI. Friday

My speculations upon the Patronage Bill have all of a sudden met with a check, from a slackening of thought in the midst of the argument, and from a call to other objects— Alfred this day left us, and I returned him to his mother; by whom he had been bound by an Indenture to my Son. I have not been able to find the deed— There were yet four or five years of his time to run; but we were so much dissatisfied with him, that we thought it best to discharge him; and have taken a young black man, named Augustus in his place— I was much occupied in making out a list of Postmasters in the Towns of the 12th. Congressional district of Massachusetts, and answered a Letter from Frederick Kretschmar a German at Philadelphia, who has made a German Translation of my Oration, on the Life and Character of La Fayette, and wishes me to read it, and advise him whether to send it to Germany for publication. Mr Van Buren, the Vice-President paid me a morning visit— Our conversation was upon the surprizing growth and increase of the City and State of New-York, in the half century since I landed there from France in July 1785. when the population of the City was less than twenty-thousand Souls— It is now little short of two hundred and forty thousand, and still increasing with unexampled rapidity— He remarked that very few persons had made fortunes by this course of Events, although the rise in the price of Lands had kept full pace with the growth of population— That John Jacob Astor, had systematically invested his property in Lands and had now an Estate worth thirteen or fourteen, some said fifteen Millions of Dollars— He said he himself had foolishly two or three years since sold the greater part of his own Estate in Lands, and that now the same lands were worth at least forty per-cent more than he sold them for I observed that the creation of Banks and of Bank paper, aggravated heavily the price of Lands— He said that was true, and very obvious; and it was surprizing that People would not see it— This was the nearest approach that we made to politics— My morning walk was abridged, and I was not out after dinner.
25. VI. Saturday.

Farther waste of time in making out an alphabetical list of Postmasters in the two Counties of Norfolk and Plymouth, Massachusetts, and a list of members of the House of Representatives in the Massachusetts Legislature, from the towns in the 12th. Congressional District. These lists are made with a view to the distributions of public documents of which an extra number of copies are printed by order of the House of Representatives for circulation— This must be systematically done, and the system that I have heretofore pursued is susceptible of improvement.
One of the Clerks from the war department, came from the Secretary Cass to enquire the name of a young man of Dorchester, Massachusetts, for whom he had promised me a Warrant of admission as a Cadet at West-Point for June 1836. I gave him the name from memory, and mistook the middle initial. I afterwards recurred to his Letter, and went to the Department, where the warrant was already made out—the error was rectified, and I took the warrant with me, properly directed to Samuel B. Howe— He is required to repair to West-Point, between the 1st and 20th. of June 1836— Mr Cass told me that Mr Rush and Coll. Howard had not succeeded in their mission to Ohio and Michigan— That the Commissioners from Ohio had run their line, and the Government of the State was exercising jurisdiction, from which he expected a conflict and blood shed— He asked me if I had read the opinion of the Attorney General on the dispute— I said I had; and regretted to see in it what I had understood as a surrender of the right of Michigan to the lands— He said it was not so intended nor so understood in Ohio—I said the opinion was certainly against the present pretensions of Ohio, but I thought the right was surrendered by the concession that although Congress had not formally acceded to the proposition in the Constitution of the State of Ohio, they had reserved the right of acceding to it thereafter— He said it was only that they had the same right now, which they had then— That they had not the moral right, but that they possessed the legal right; there being no restriction upon Congress as there was upon the States, against passing Laws impairing the obligation of contracts— I said that was enough, and I considered it as a surrender of the question— I did not admit the right of Congress to pass Laws in violation of their own contracts; and added it was precisely question with the French chamber of deputies. There was a heavy hot gale from the Southwest this morning; and a Cold gust from the Northwest followed by thunder, lightening and rain in the Evening— I was taking a short walk, and went in to Mr W. S. Smith and spent an hour with Mr and Mrs Smith. Augustus brought me an umbrella, and with the help of a Cloak and Lantern borrowed I got home without a drenching.
26. V:30. Sunday.

Rain all night and morning. At the Presbyterian Church,—heard Mr Smith from Matthew 21.28. [“]But what think ye? a certain man had two sons; and he came to the first, and said Son, go work to day in my vineyard. 29. He answered and said, I will not: but afterward he repented and went. 30. And he came to the second, and said likewise. And he answered and said, I go, Sir: and went not. 31. Whether of them twain did the will of his father? They say unto him, the first. Jesus saith unto them, Verily, I say unto you, that the publicans and the harlots go into the kingdom of God before you. 32. For John came unto you in the way of righteousness, and ye believed him not: but the publicans and the harlots believed him: and ye, when ye had seen it, repented not afterward, that ye might believe him.” The discourse was an extemporaneous commentary on the parable— Mr Smith gave notice that he should leave the City to-morrow, to be absent two or three weeks— But he exhorted his auditory to attend Church as if he were here— Afternoon at St John’s Church
Mr Hawley read the service for the first Sunday after Easter; and preached from Psalm 67.4—O, let the Nations be glad, and sing for joy; for thou shalt judge the people righteously, and govern the Nations upon Earth. Selah— The auditory both parts of the day, very small— I read Dr Bancroft’s 25th. Sermon, on the Institutions of the Gospel; baptism and the communion—and the 26th. On the doctrine of endless punishment. He says that from a diligent examination of the New Testament he is satisfied that it does not contain the doctrine of punishment endless in duration— But that he as fully believes that the sanction of the divine law will be inflicted— I answered a Letter from Dr Waterhouse—
27. VI. Monday

And now I am obliged to abandon almost entirely my speculations upon the patronage Bill, and other public concerns, and devote my time to private affairs— Much of the day was employed in filing, and assorting my Letters, of which I have yet a great and increasing number unanswered— I have read somewhere in an account of Dr Price’s life that he was much distressed in his old age with his correspondence; and Voltaire when at Ferney, says he has ten or twelve Letters to answer every day— I can scarcely ever answer more than one—and the want of a Secretary after having had one or more, for thirty years of my life is a grievous deficiency— This day I began to make out an Administration account; but was soon obliged to suspend the labour— Mr Frye called; and I was unable to find a minute which he gave me some weeks since, respecting the distribution of the late Thomas J. Hellen’s Estate— I spoke again to urge the final distribution of the former Walter Hellen’s Estate between his surviving children— I answered a Letter from a Frenchman named M. de Saussure who writes to me from Philadelphia, to enquire if I can give him any tidings of his brother; who he says three years since came from France to this Country with Letters to me— He thinks one from the late General La Fayette— His relatives received Letters from him written at New-York and afterwards at the Mansion house Hotel at Philadelphia— He was then just coming to deliver his Letters to me, and from that time they have heard nothing of or from him— But he never delivered any Letter to me, nor had I ever heard of his name till I received this Letter from his brother— I walked up to the foot of Capitol hill, and back before dinner, with a sprinkling as I went out, and a drenching rain as I came back.
28 VI. Tuesday.

Interruption of purpose, and abstraction from the preparation of my account. Much occupied in assorting and filing Letters— I returned the visit of Vice-President Van Buren, and our conversation was of a balloon ascension of a man named Clayton, from somewhere in Ohio, who was nine hours and a half in the air, and at half past two O’Clock in the Morning landed upon a hill top in the Allegheny mountains three hundred and fifty miles from the place of his departure.
We spoke also of a foot race lately run for a premium of 1000 dollars near New-York and won by a Connecticut farmer— Ten miles in one hour. He performed it in 59 minutes 48. Seconds— Two others, foreigners, came within one minute of success. There were nine competitors for the prize. And immediately after the atchievement two persons offered themselves to undertake to walk five hundred miles without eating or drinking, for a prize of 500 dollars— Another subject of conversation was the Temperance reform— Another the condition and prospects of the Roman Catholic Religion in this Country— No Politics— He told me that Mr Delavan, the great Patron of the Temperance cause at Albany, had poured into the gutters some hundred of bottles of the finest old Madeira wine— He would neither drink it himself, nor sell it to be drank by others— I applied at Fischer’s shop, to have a new Diary volume bound for me, and then went to the Congress Library, where from the first volume of Cranch’s Reports, I made some extracts from the Report of the case of Marbury and Madison— The Court in that case held that the President appoints the Officers of the United States; but they held that the President had not the power to remove Justices of Peace in the District of Columbia because the Law, fixed the tenure of their Offices, for five years— Mr Jefferson however did remove them and they were never restored. My evening was engaged in replying to a Letter from my Son.
29. V:30. Wednesday.

Finished the Letter to my Son, and returned to the preparation of my account; which absorbed the greater part of the day and was yet left unfinished: but no small portion of the time is wasted upon trifles I wrote also a few lines in answer to Lorrain Pease of Poquonock Connecticut, where a number of young men have formed a social Library, and wrote to request a Copy of my Oration on the Life and Character of La Fayette— I sent them one, and with it an Eulogy on James Monroe, and an Address to the Inhabitants of Quincy on the Anniversary of Independence 1831— My grand child Louisa was taken with a faint and sick turn while reading to me this morning, and was confined to the nursery the remainder of the day— I hear her and her Sister read every morning when they are well.— I took my walk round the Capitol Hill before dinner. The wind has come round to the South and the weather is warm— After dinner, I read part of one of the Essays on a Congress of Nations for the preservation of Peace— Dull and Heavy work— In the Evening a young man by the name of Langtree a native of Ireland, brought me a Letter of introduction from William H. Stone of New-York— Mr Langtree has been some time at the University of Edinburgh, for education to the Medical Profession; but he has been two or three years in this Country, and has now a place as a Clerk in the Ordinance bureau of the War Department. He appears to have a warm attachment to Literature, and extensive reading classical, as well as of modern times— His conversation was interesting, and quite uncommon here— Mr Frye, and Mr Johnson were here this morning; and Walter Hellen from Alexandria; but he did not stay.
30. VI. Thursday.

Mr Force called upon me this morning, and gave me a handsomely bound copy of his National Calendar for the present year— He referred me to a passage in the Oration upon the Life and Character of La Fayette, where he thought there was a mistake— It referred to the Flag of the United States, as he thought at the time of the Declaration of Independence and mentioned it as consisting of the Stars and the Stripes— He said that
was not the flag of the United States until 1777. (14 June 1777) It happened that my words apply to the time when La Fayette repaired to the Standard; which being the 1st. of August 1777. they were not incorrect; but they would not be so, for the time when he left France, to repair to the Standard; which was in March 1777— Force had got a number of extracts from the Newspapers of the time, concerning the preceding flag which was a white field with yellow stripes and a Rattlesnake, with the motto “don’t tread on me”— But he said he could not find how, or when, or by whom it had been ordained— I urged Mr Force, to improve his Calendar in future years, by adding to it an Almanack, and the Post Offices The Almanack, he said he certainly would, and the Post-Offices if possible—but he said he had made proposals, both at the general Post-Office and at the Department of State, to include their annual and biennial Registers in his Calendar; but although he had offered exceedingly advantageous terms they had been rejected, because he was not of the right faith— I gave Mr Force a copy of the last Edition of the Oration upon the Life and character of La Fayette— In my walk round the Capitol Hill, I met E. Wyer and took him round with me—belating him a little for his dinner, for which he was engaged at 3. at Dr. Huntt’s— He amused me with his Politics, and announced to me that he was a White man— Dr Kuhl, a German travelling physician and inventor of medical nostrums came to put his list of all-healing specifics in my hands; and to engage the shop in the Pennsylvania Avenue lately occupied by Mrs Doyne; which he agreed to take by the month at the rate of 150 dollars a year.— I sent Borland the Carpenter to make an estimate of the further repairs claimed by Mrs Wolfenden, and they will at least absorb the quarter’s Rent— I received and answered a Letter from my Son, respecting the Quincy Quarries; which have been among my troubles— Governor Cass the Secretary of War, and General Macomb paid me an Evening visit together— I had also a morning visit from Mr Richard Derby of Boston, lately returned from Europe where he has been passing two years since the death of his wife— He spoke to me also of the sudden death of his nephew Coll. Benjn. T. Pickman; and said it had almost broken the hearts of his father and mother, who is Mr Derby’s Sister— He has been much out of health, and looks very old—but says he is now well

Day— I rise now with tolerable regularity at six— Read four chapters in the Bible, and very little else before breakfast— But I hear my two grand daughters Mary Louisa, and Georgiana Frances read— At once a tedious task and an exquisite pleasure— It employs about one hour every morning— We breakfast about nine, and newspapers, and interruptions swallow up the succeeding hours, with whatever little business of any kind that I can do till past two— Then I walk an hour and a half till four, at which time we dine— After dinner I read and write till the dusk of evening; and then after about an hour’s interval write again till near eleven— This Life is little diversified. My writing has been for the month in this Diary— Sundry Letters, chiefly to my Son and two sketches of a Speech against Calhoun’s Patronage Bill— Neither of them yet finished—and in going over the subject the second time, I find swarms of faults in what I had thought beauties of the first draught— I was when that was written, little acquainted with the subject; and although much better versed in it now, should learn much more concerning it, and believe I shall be as much dissatisfied with the second, as I was with the first.— Meditation is inexhaustible, but must have an end.
